Class presentation (5%)

This component is voluntary. These bonus marks can be earned by presenting a weblinked article embedded in the lecture slides. The first presentation will be worth 2 marks, and the second 3 marks for a total of 5 marks. Your efforts to earn these marks will be taken into account in deciding your final mark.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"67b31e83dba13450be4672f5f39619d6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"67b31e83dba13450be4672f5f39619da","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"67b31e83dba13450be4672f5f39619db","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO10","cl_id":"6fb31e83dba13450be4672f5f39619d6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"6fb31e83dba13450be4672f5f39619d8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"6fb31e83dba13450be4672f5f39619db","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2bb35e83dba13450be4672f5f3961900","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final examination (60%)","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"60","description":"

Final Examination (60%)

This test has the standard 2 minutes allowed per assessment mark, i.e. 120 minutes, plus 10 minutes reading time, giving a total of 2 hours 10 minutes. This assessment may be multiple choice questions or written short answer questions similar to that of the Class Quiz, or a combination of both. More information on the format of the assessment will be provided later on Moodle. No past examination papers will be posted on the Moodle. Past experience shows that the availability of past year examination questions do not help students with answering questions in the examinations. Students were found to memorise the solutions to the past year papers, and to reproduce the answers, without reference to the question asked in the final examination. It is important that you study the lecture notes, work through the textbook questions, and read and understand the case studies in the weblinks, in order to do well in the final examination.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"67b31e83dba13450be4672f5f39619d6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"67b31e83dba13450be4672f5f39619d7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"67b31e83dba13450be4672f5f39619d8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"67b31e83dba13450be4672f5f39619db","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6fb31e83dba13450be4672f5f39619d7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"6fb31e83dba13450be4672f5f39619d8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6fb31e83dba13450be4672f5f39619d9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO12","cl_id":"6fb31e83dba13450be4672f5f39619da","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"37b35e83dba13450be4672f5f3961908","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Class quiz (10%)","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Class Quiz (10%)

The Quiz will be an in-class test, consisting of written short answer type questions. You will be required to analyse a case, applying the Financial Reporting and Earnings Quality framework introduced in week 1. As a rule of thumb in this course, 2 minutes is allowed for each assessment mark. As such this Quiz should have 20 minutes allocated to it. However, as it is the first significant assessment that students encounter for this course, additional time is allowed for it.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ACCT5908 - Auditing and Assurance Services","description":"

This course examines the practice of auditing, the underlying concepts, auditors’ responsibilities and the audit environment. Although the focus of attention is on audits carried out under the provisions of the Corporations Law, reference is also made to other assurance and related non-assurance services. The course is intended to provide an overview of the audit process as it exists in Australia and internationally. Focus is on both the conduct of the audit (as an auditor) and interaction with the audit function (as a member of the business community). Topics include: risk based auditing approach; assessment of risk; development of audit strategy; internal control evaluation and compliance testing; substantive testing; analytical review; auditing in an information technology environment; audit sampling; audit reporting; contractual and common law duties; the critical role of ethics; and an introduction to other assurance and related non-assurance services.

Foundation Knowledge Quiz (5%)

Reflecting the importance of the foundation material introduced in the first two seminars, Foundation Knowledge Quiz will provide students with feedback on their understanding of this material.

Seminar Preparation (5%)

In five (5) seminars (Seminars 3,4,6,7 and 8), students are asked to complete advance preparation questions relevant to the practical case set down for application and discussion in that particular seminar class.

Final Examination (50%)

Students are required to sit a Final Exam in this course. The Final examination covers the entire course.

Mid-Term Examination (20%)

The Mid-Term Examination covers material from Seminars 1 to 4 (inclusive). The aim of the Mid-Term Examination is to provide students with ongoing feedback relating to your understanding and learning progress within the course.

Group Assignment (20%)

The aim of the group assignment (comprising 20% of overall assessment) is to provide students an opportunity to work in a group setting to analyse audit issues and suggest responses thereto. The successful completion of the assignment will require consistent effort throughout the term. An important aspect of the assignment will be to demonstrate the ability to present a written report in a professional manner.

?Current Developments in Auditing Research is designed to extend disciplinary perspectives in auditing and provide training for research in auditing and assurance services. The course focuses on current areas of research in auditing and related assurance services. The following topics will be covered: some of the main empirical and theoretical developments in auditing research; the main research methods used in auditing research; alternative research methods; the practical implications of current research in auditing; the relationship of research to practice and standard-setting, and statistical tools to use in audit research.

contentlets.description: ?Current Developments in Auditing Research is designed to extend disciplinary perspectives in auditing and provide training for research in auditing and assurance services. The course focuses on current areas of research in auditing and related assurance services. The following topics will be covered: some of the main empirical and theoretical developments in auditing research; the main research methods used in auditing research; alternative research methods; the practical implications of current research in auditing; the relationship of research to practice and standard-setting, and statistical tools to use in audit research.

Note: Not available to students who have completed ACCT3610 in the last three years.


This course examines the: sources of information available to analysts; traditional ratio analysis; application of techniques of financial analysis to equity valuation; credit assessment; and price regulation. Also looked at are: calculations of key indicators of financial performance; issues arising from international differences in accounting standards and practices; off-balance sheet financing and financial instruments; problems arising from complex organisational structures; and strategies for managing the financial analysis function.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"d6d356c3dba13450be4672f5f3961906","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

The final examination will be a two hour examination at a time to be advised via the examination timetable. All material covered in the course is examinable. The aim of the final exam is to assess if you have achieved an adequate level of technical competency in financial statement analysis and the capacity to apply the technical competency analytically and critically in a business environment.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"26d356c3dba13450be4672f5f3961908","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"26d356c3dba13450be4672f5f3961909","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"26d356c3dba13450be4672f5f396190b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2ed356c3dba13450be4672f5f3961907","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"2ed356c3dba13450be4672f5f3961908","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"22d356c3dba13450be4672f5f3961927","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Major Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

The major project is aimed at developing your understanding of, and practical skills in financial statement analysis and valuation. It is also designed to enhance teamwork, and analytical and communication skills. Upon successful completion of the project you will have acquired a working knowledge and practical skills in undertaking an equity valuation using ‘leading-edge’ financial statement analysis techniques. From past experience, the final report often provides excellent evidence of your analytical skills that can presented to prospective employers when applying for jobs.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"26d356c3dba13450be4672f5f3961907","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"26d356c3dba13450be4672f5f3961908","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"26d356c3dba13450be4672f5f3961909","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"26d356c3dba13450be4672f5f396190a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"26d356c3dba13450be4672f5f396190b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2ed356c3dba13450be4672f5f3961907","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"2ed356c3dba13450be4672f5f3961909","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"2ed356c3dba13450be4672f5f396190a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2ed356c3dba13450be4672f5f396191c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Class Participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Performance","value":"performance"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

The course will be taught in a discussion mode to facilitate thoughtful discussion of the cases. To get the most out of the course, you must be prepared for discussion every week. You should come to class with a list of questions on everything you do not understand, and you should be prepared to discuss your opinions on professional issues. In other words, you do not have to have a specific question in order to participate.

Participation marks will be awarded based on your weekly hand-ins. There will be questions assigned for each class. You should submit your response through the Turnitin link provided on the Course Moodle page. You must also bring a hard copy of your submission to class. Feedback will be provided from attending class and participating in the discussion surrounding these weekly questions.

Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"ACCT5914","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ACCT5914 - Enterprise Strategy for Management Accountants","description":"

Formulating and implementing strategy depends on a thorough understanding of all aspects of an organisation; making sound business decisions requires advanced management accounting knowledge including both financial and strategic analysis. This course uses relevant, globally focused business cases for students to learn how management accountants formulate and effectively implement strategy while managing risk, using the competencies gained in earlier management accounting courses. Integrating research and practice, this advanced course is designed to equip students with relevant management accounting skills that will enable them to influence strategic decisions and manage performance. Topics include interacting with the competitive environment, understanding the business partner role of management accountants in change management, evaluating strategic options using leading management accounting techniques, and implementing strategic plans via performance management systems.

contentlets.description: Formulating and implementing strategy depends on a thorough understanding of all aspects of an organisation; making sound business decisions requires advanced management accounting knowledge including both financial and strategic analysis. This course uses relevant, globally focused business cases for students to learn how management accountants formulate and effectively implement strategy while managing risk, using the competencies gained in earlier management accounting courses. Integrating research and practice, this advanced course is designed to equip students with relevant management accounting skills that will enable them to influence strategic decisions and manage performance. Topics include interacting with the competitive environment, understanding the business partner role of management accountants in change management, evaluating strategic options using leading management accounting techniques, and implementing strategic plans via performance management systems.
contentlets.title: Enterprise Strategy for Management Accountants

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ACCT5919 - Business Risk Management","description":"

In a rapidly changing global world, with decreasing product life cycles and increasing customer and societal expectations, there are significant and increased risks associated with ongoing value creation by organisations. In this world, value is put at risk - by competition, or failures of corporate leadership, strategies, processes, and capabilities. Developing effective ways of managing such Business Risks is proving to be a central agenda item for organisations seeking continuing success. This course addresses this emergent field conceptually, technically and speculatively. Case studies and research reports are used throughout.

Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"ACCT5920","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ACCT5920 - Managing Intangible Resources","description":"

This course seeks to understand intangible asset issues from a management accounting, financial accounting and auditing perspective. The gap between the market value of firms and the capitalisation of their assets in the balance sheet highlights the value that investors are prepared to attribute to the "intangible resources" of many organisations (such as financial service, consulting, software development and e-commerce companies). The value generating potential of such organisations is attributed to resources, and competencies in managing these resources, that the traditional accounting system is often both unable and unwilling to represent in explicit financial terms. Based on the premise that long term sustainable value creation is best achieved from collaborative organisational practices and transparency among all stakeholders, this course aims to identify these "intangible resources" and to examine their role in achieving superior financial performance. The course examines how intangible assets are treated from a financial accounting perspective given International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS), and offers a critical understanding of measurement and auditing challenges. Additionally, the course incorporates performance measurement frameworks that seek to represent intangible resources often not captured within conventional accounting systems (for example, the Balanced Scorecard and other methodologies that seek to meaningfully measure and evaluate intangibles). The types of intangible resources captured within such frameworks and how they are measured is examined also.

Individual Essay (40%)

Students are required to hand in an Essay on Intangibles (and their measurement within contemporary organisations)

Individual Case Presentation (15%)

Storytelling is a powerful tool for business executives. Each individual will have an opportunity to present in class during a selected week of semester. The idea is to prepare and execute an innovative presentation that conveys significant issues relating to any topic in the course. In doing so, students are required to present in such a way that a compelling story is told and  also develop strategies to get audience (classmates) involved.

Note: Not available to students who have completed ACCT3585 in the last three years.


The business world today operates on a global, networked, technology platform (the World Wide Web). The rapid implementation of networked technologies world wide has impacted national economies and transformed large and small organisations.


This course uses case studies of high performing e-businesses to facilitate discussion and understanding of the strategic, technological, operational and organisational changes required by organisations to remain competitive, as they confront the strategic opportunities and threats resulting from the global networked technologies.


The case studies analyse the emergence of new business models, including start up e-businesses, the transformation of traditional bricks and mortar companies into e-businesses and the creation of virtual global businesses with outsourced functions performed by a range of specialist companies.


The course also studies the move to digitalised core processes across the value chain– the e-enabling of customer relations; the e-enabling of enterprise resource planning, financial and accounting processes and human resource processes; and the emergence of global, digitalised supply chains. It reviews the financial opportunities the technologies provide to reduce costs, improve productivity and efficiency, and transform concepts of speed and flexibility.

contentlets.description:
Note: Not available to students who have completed ACCT3585 in the last three years.

The business world today operates on a global, networked, technology platform (the World Wide Web). The rapid implementation of networked technologies world wide has impacted national economies and transformed large and small organisations.

This course uses case studies of high performing e-businesses to facilitate discussion and understanding of the strategic, technological, operational and organisational changes required by organisations to remain competitive, as they confront the strategic opportunities and threats resulting from the global networked technologies.

The case studies analyse the emergence of new business models, including start up e-businesses, the transformation of traditional bricks and mortar companies into e-businesses and the creation of virtual global businesses with outsourced functions performed by a range of specialist companies.

The course also studies the move to digitalised core processes across the value chain– the e-enabling of customer relations; the e-enabling of enterprise resource planning, financial and accounting processes and human resource processes; and the emergence of global, digitalised supply chains. It reviews the financial opportunities the technologies provide to reduce costs, improve productivity and efficiency, and transform concepts of speed and flexibility.
contentlets.title: E-Business: Strategy and Processes

Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"ACCT5925","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ACCT5925 - Integrated Reporting, Integrated Thinking and Value Creation","description":"

This course is concerned with how organisations create and preserve value over time employing effective business models and a broader range of resources (capitals) than in conventional analyses. This value creation process is currently being reported upon under the international initiative of Integrated Reporting <IR>, incorporating Integrated Thinking, which is enhancing the way organizations think holistically, plan strategically and report value outcomes. Integrated Thinking focuses on how executives make business decisions that best utilise all their available resources and relationships (not just financial but including their staff, intellectual property, environmental, and supplier and customer relationships) to implement a strategy for long term value creation. Integrated Reporting then focuses on how they communicate (both internally and to external stakeholders) their unique value creation story, in order to address the question, “Why should I, or others in society, support this organisation?” The course is designed to be highly interactive with many illustrations and cases.


Topics include: The drivers behind the development of the International Framework; creating value over time with Integrated Thinking; and implementation including the design of an internal management system geared to value management rather than traditional financial management.


Acknowledgement is made of the significant contributions of KPMG Australia and the International Integrated Reporting Council in developing and presenting the course. This is an approved <IR> Training course.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"7d145a07dba13450be4672f5f3961927","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Milestone Report - Case Study","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Case Study - Milestone (20%) – Individual report

This assessment is designed to monitor the progress of students’ knowledge and understanding of important aspects of integrated reporting, particularly on the elements of value creation. In preparing the milestone, students are required to use the corporate report of a specific company preparing an integrated report. This will also be the basis of the group case study later in the semester. The milestone requires a one-page individual report due in Week 6. Further details regarding this assessment will be provided in Week 1.
 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO10","cl_id":"b5145a07dba13450be4672f5f3961929","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b5145a07dba13450be4672f5f396192a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"b5145a07dba13450be4672f5f396192b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b5145a07dba13450be4672f5f396192c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"bd145a07dba13450be4672f5f3961929","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"bd145a07dba13450be4672f5f396192c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"bd145a07dba13450be4672f5f396192d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"02145a07dba13450be4672f5f3961936","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

In-class quizzes (20%)

Students will sit two quizzes at the beginning of the seminars in Week 3 and Week 8. The quizzes will consist of a mix of multiple choice, short answer and application questions. These quizzes will test your understanding of key concepts, definitions and your ability to apply the concepts in business situations. Coverage of quizzes will be announced at the start of the term.
 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO10","cl_id":"b5145a07dba13450be4672f5f3961929","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b5145a07dba13450be4672f5f396192a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b5145a07dba13450be4672f5f396192c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"bd145a07dba13450be4672f5f396192c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"bd145a07dba13450be4672f5f396192d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"31145a07dba13450be4672f5f396192f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Class Participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

Class Participation (20%)

Key aims of the seminar engagement are two-fold, that is, to encourage timely and active independent learning and facilitate peer-based knowledge sharing.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO10","cl_id":"b5145a07dba13450be4672f5f3961929","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b5145a07dba13450be4672f5f396192c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"b5145a07dba13450be4672f5f396192d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"bd145a07dba13450be4672f5f3961929","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"bd145a07dba13450be4672f5f396192a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"bd145a07dba13450be4672f5f396192b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"bd145a07dba13450be4672f5f396192d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ce145a07dba13450be4672f5f396193e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Case Study","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Case Study (40%)

The group will be required to do a task that will cover the fundamental concepts, Guiding Principles and Content Elements of the Integrated Reporting Framework.

The requirements include group a written report (25%) in PowerPoint slide format and a video presentation (15%) of group findings. The video should contain a two-minute presentation from each student. The mark for this assessment is broken down into 5% group mark and 10% individual mark.

Accounting","description":"

This course examines the fundamentals of financial accounting for entities of simple organisational design; financial recording processes, systems design and internal control; preparation of general purpose statements of financial position, operating performance and cash flow statements; responsibilities in financial reporting; financial reporting constraints; recognition and measurement of specific financial statement elements; and analysis and interpretation of financial reports.

Final Exam (60%)

Students are required to sit a Final Examination in this course. The Final Examination will cover material from the entire course. Students must achieve a satisfactory level of performance in the Final Examination to be eligible for a passing grade.

Online Practice Set (15%)

In order to improve students’ book-keeping skills, a practice set will be available for them to work on throughout the course. The practice set is completed online and submitted in stages. Feedback will be immediately provided each time that work is submitted.

Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"ACCT5931","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ACCT5931 - Strategic Management Accounting","description":"

This course introduces emergent thinking about the interfaces between financial and business performance with a focus on adding value to the business, rather than emphasising financial control. The link between strategy and resource management is highlighted, in focusing on the effective use of an organisation’s financial and other resources in creating value for customers and shareholders. The course aims to introduce strategic financial management as an integrated way of thinking about the key drivers of value in organisations.

Note: Not available to students who have completed ACCT2542 in the last three years.


ACCT5942 examines the preparation of external financial reports by corporate groups that are reporting entities in accordance with the Corporation Act, 2001 (Cth). The primary learning objective of the course is to apply the techniques of group accounting including consolidation accounting, equity accounting and the line-by-line method for jointly controlled operations or jointly controlled assets.

contentlets.description:
Note: Not available to students who have completed ACCT2542 in the last three years.

ACCT5942 examines the preparation of external financial reports by corporate groups that are reporting entities in accordance with the Corporation Act, 2001 (Cth). The primary learning objective of the course is to apply the techniques of group accounting including consolidation accounting, equity accounting and the line-by-line method for jointly controlled operations or jointly controlled assets.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ACCT5943 - Advanced Financial Reporting","description":"

Note: Not available to students who have completed ACCT3563 or ACCT3573 in the last three years.


This course introduces students to special topics relating to Australian financial reporting with an emphasis on recognition and measurement of assets and liabilities. It focuses on the analysis of a range of contemporary accounting issues within theoretical frameworks such as agency theory and systems-oriented theories; and from the perspective of the conceptual framework used in setting accounting standards.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c4549a47dba13450be4672f5f39619fb","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Syndicate Research Project 10%","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Syndicate Research Project 10%

You are required to work on this project in syndicate groups of maximum four students. Details about the syndicate research project will be announced in the first class. By the end of week 1, you should be a member of a syndicate. If you have difficulties forming such groups, please contact your lecturer as soon as possible.

contentlets.description:
Note: Not available to students who have completed ACCT3563 or ACCT3573 in the last three years.

This course introduces students to special topics relating to Australian financial reporting with an emphasis on recognition and measurement of assets and liabilities. It focuses on the analysis of a range of contemporary accounting issues within theoretical frameworks such as agency theory and systems-oriented theories; and from the perspective of the conceptual framework used in setting accounting standards.
contentlets.title: Advanced Financial Reporting

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ACCT5949 - Managing Agile Organisations","description":"

This course examines agility in organisations via a range of readings, both contemporary and seminal, providing insights into this aspect of competitive contemporary organisations. A range of concepts address what is leadership, management, agile organisations, and examines various resources that managers (including those in accounting and finance functions) can mobilise in developing and sustaining agile organisations.

Research - Financial","description":"

Enrolment requires School Approval. Review of alternative approaches to the development of theories in external reporting. Explication and evaluation of substantive theories and associated research studies. Examination of research findings related to the accounting and reporting environment, agency cost and financial contracting, the properties of reported accounting numbers, predictive value of accounting information, the use of information in capital markets, and the use of accounting reports by individual decision makers.

Paper Critique (25%)

This will involve the writing of a critical review of an assigned paper. Further guidance will be provided in Class, as will the formatting and style requirements.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d764d287dba13450be4672f5f39619f2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d764d287dba13450be4672f5f39619f3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"df64d287dba13450be4672f5f39619f1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1364d287dba13450be4672f5f39619f5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Replication Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

Replication Assignment (25%)

This will involve the replication of the results of an assigned paper. Further guidance will be offered in class. Style and formatting requirements will be described in a separate instruction sheet.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d764d287dba13450be4672f5f39619f2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d764d287dba13450be4672f5f39619f3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"df64d287dba13450be4672f5f39619f1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1f64d287dba13450be4672f5f39619f9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

Research Proposal (30%)

This will involve the writing of a short proposal for extending extant research on a topic either suggested in Class or of your choice. Further guidance will be offered in class. Style and formatting requirements will be described in a separate instruction sheet.

Research - Managerial","description":"

The aim of this course is to equip students with a comprehensive understanding of contemporary management accounting research, which emanates from different philosophical perspectives and employs different theories and research methods. Research is divided into two broad streams: work that seeks (a) to explain and design, and (b) to understand and interpret the practice of management accounting in organisations and  societies. A variety of contemporary topics will be addressed using behavioural decision theory, contingency theory, institutional theory, and socio-material approaches.

Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"ACCT5955","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ACCT5955 - Management Control Systems in Contemporary Contexts","description":"

This course examines the design, implementation and uses of Management Control Systems (MCS) within contemporary contexts. There is a consideration of how designs of MCS are changing given globalisation, new technologies, digitalisation, and increasingly blurred organisational boundaries. The content is less technically oriented than a typical management accounting course and provides a broader strategic perspective of management control issues from the viewpoint of the CFO (Chief Financial Officer) and the senior executive team. The course is designed to be highly interactive. It encourages the application of reading materials to cases and critical reflections on the effectiveness of different MCS on performance in various organisational settings.

Major Team Presentation (10%)

Each Team will make a presentation on a combined set of analysis and findings from the above individual applied research.

Major Team Assignment (with Self Reflection Statement) (20%)

This assignment will involve significant applied research in relation to management control systems. The written component of this assignment is a team effort. Students will engage with these issues in real industry examples throughout the course and in their main assignment.

Individual Participation in Class Activities (5%)

Each student is expected to contribute to the seminar discussion and class activities.  Individual students will be assigned a participation mark ranging from 0 to 10, based on their contributions to the classroom discussion. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e1749687dba13450be4672f5f396198b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e1749687dba13450be4672f5f396198c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"e1749687dba13450be4672f5f396198d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"e9749687dba13450be4672f5f396198b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e9749687dba13450be4672f5f396198c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e9749687dba13450be4672f5f396198d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b1749687dba13450be4672f5f39619d5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Individual Case Presentation (15%)","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

Individual Case Presentation (15%)

This is an individually marked effort where an opportunity is given to review and reflect on any topic in the area of management control (covered in the course). You will be asked to prepare an innovative presentation related to a topic from weeks 1-5. Role plays, television format and other innovative presentation styles are encouraged and you must tell a story.

contentlets.description: This course examines the design, implementation and uses of Management Control Systems (MCS) within contemporary contexts. There is a consideration of how designs of MCS are changing given globalisation, new technologies, digitalisation, and increasingly blurred organisational boundaries. The content is less technically oriented than a typical management accounting course and provides a broader strategic perspective of management control issues from the viewpoint of the CFO (Chief Financial Officer) and the senior executive team. The course is designed to be highly interactive. It encourages the application of reading materials to cases and critical reflections on the effectiveness of different MCS on performance in various organisational settings.
contentlets.title: Management Control Systems in Contemporary Contexts

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ACCT5961 - Reporting for Climate Change and Sustainability","description":"

Climate change and sustainability are key challenges for our society and economy today. Governments and non-governmental organisations around the world have engaged in various climate change and adaptation policy initiatives to ensure survival and prosperity of current and future generations. 

This course explores issues related to climate change and sustainability and the implications for industry sectors and businesses. Established and proposed policy frameworks are surveyed and evaluated to highlight the significance of transparency and accountability in reporting economic, environmental, and social performance. The current state and trends in accounting, assurance and reporting for carbon emissions in a regulated and voluntary setting will be covered. Risk mitigation and management accounting strategies to respond to consequences of a carbon-constrained economy are also evaluated.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"94849a87dba13450be4672f5f3961930","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Individual Essay: Content Analysis of Sustainability Reports","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Individual Essay (30%) - Content Analysis of a CSR/Sustainability Report

This is an individual written assignment for students to gain knowledge of information typically provided in sustainability reports. A company will be allocated to each student to perform a content analysis of a sustainability report. As part of this assessment students will identify the company’s approach to sustainability, identify the company’s initiatives with regards to social and environmental impacts of the company’s business operations and then critically evaluate the company’s strategy and its effect on the company’s performance.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d4849a87dba13450be4672f5f3961932","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d4849a87dba13450be4672f5f3961933","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"dc849a87dba13450be4672f5f3961931","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"dc849a87dba13450be4672f5f3961932","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"dc849a87dba13450be4672f5f3961933","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"68849a87dba13450be4672f5f3961935","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Carbon Footprinting Exercise","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Personal Carbon Footprinting Exercise (20%)

This activity aims to demonstrate ability of students to perform GHG calculations. More information will be provided on Moodle at the start of term. The report is due in Week 8. Details of submission will be announced on Moodle closer to the date.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d4849a87dba13450be4672f5f3961932","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"dc849a87dba13450be4672f5f3961931","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"dc849a87dba13450be4672f5f3961932","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"dc849a87dba13450be4672f5f3961933","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"68849a87dba13450be4672f5f396193c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group Case Study Written Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Comprehensive Case Study (30%)

The case study is expected to develop critical thinking and problem solving skills in students.  This case will also provide students the opportunity to apply the knowledge learnt from the course.  This assessment is a group effort hence students should work together for a common purpose and students should take this opportunity to develop their teamwork skills. Members of the group will generally be awarded a common mark based on the quality of the written assignment. However, if there are material inconsistencies in the contribution of group members, the lecturer reserves the right to vary the group mark after consultation with the group members.  

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d4849a87dba13450be4672f5f3961932","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d4849a87dba13450be4672f5f3961933","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"d4849a87dba13450be4672f5f3961934","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"dc849a87dba13450be4672f5f3961931","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"dc849a87dba13450be4672f5f3961932","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"dc849a87dba13450be4672f5f3961933","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e0849a87dba13450be4672f5f3961942","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar Engagement","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

Seminar Engagement (20%)

Key aims of the seminar engagement are two-fold, that is, to encourage timely and active independent learning and facilitate peer-based knowledge sharing.

Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"ACCT5972","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ACCT5972 - Accounting Analytics for Business Decision Making","description":"

This course is concerned with developing students' analytical mindset. An analytics mindset is the ability to: (1) ask the right question; (2) extract, transform and load relevant data; (3) apply appropriate data analytic techniques; and (4) interpret and share the results with stakeholders.


The course gives students the opportunity to understand the importance of data and analytics to accounting and business management environments. Students complete case based problems throughout the course that require hands-on use of analytics tools. Students learn how data analytics can add value to business by providing powerful new insights to inform business decisions. Students learn to identify, interpret and use different forms of data to determine what is wrong and why it is so (technical accounting skills) as well how they would digitally communicate derived insights to stakeholders. 



Data and analytics are transforming business and have major implications for the role of graduate accountants in business. Increasingly, accountants are competing with data analysts and scientists. However, accountants are still the preferred trusted business advisors given their historic role in preparing financial information. This course is designed to give graduates a much sought after skill set which will equip them to add value to organizations in data driven business environments.


Acknowledgement is given to the Ernst & Young Foundation's Analytical Mindset Framework which informs the curriculum development of this course.


.




 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"dca416c7dba13450be4672f5f39619ab","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Team Case Project (25%)","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

Team Case Project (25%):

Team Case Project will be undertaken by a team of 6 students. The main purposes of the Team Case Project are to develop your (1) written communication skill and (2) teamwork skill. The seminar leader will allocate a team to you by the end of seminar 1. It is the student’s responsibility to be present at the seminar from Seminar 1. Any student who is not in a team by the end of seminar 3 may have to present and complete the Team Case Project individually (and must therefore suffer the consequences of having additional workload). Significant amount of applied research is required for the team to be acquainted with the company’s business environment, operations and strategies. Because many business contexts are ambiguous in nature, the Team Case Project is targeted at evaluating and providing feedback on students’ ability to apply and integrate various steps in the data analytic process, and reach the appropriate conclusions. Peer evaluations of teamwork will be used to evaluate each team member’s contributions to the Team Case Project.

Team Case Presentation (20%):

Team Case Presentation will be undertaken by a team of 6 students. The main purposes of the Team Case Project are to develop your (1) verbal communication skill and (2) teamwork skill. The seminar leader will allocate a team to you by the end of seminar 1. It is the student’s responsibility to be present at the seminar from Seminar 1. The team will present the appropriate data visualisation and reporting formats from a case study using TABLEAU as a tool. Peer evaluations of teamwork will be used to evaluate each team member’s contributions to a component of the Team Case Presentation.

Quizzes (45%)

The three quizzes are designed to test: knowledge; understanding and application of the key concepts of the weeks being evaluated.

  • Quiz 1 - Week 3 - All required readings and class activities from Weeks 1 to 3 (inclusive) - 10%

  • Quiz 2 - Week 7 - All required readings and class activities from Weeks 1 to 7 (inclusive) - 15%

  • Quiz 3 - Week 10 - All required readings and class activities from Weeks 1 to 10 (inclusive) - 20%

contentlets.keywords: accounting,accounting analytics,data analytics,visualization techniques,analytical mindset,analytical tools
contentlets.description:
This course is concerned with developing students' analytical mindset. An analytics mindset is the ability to: (1) ask the right question; (2) extract, transform and load relevant data; (3) apply appropriate data analytic techniques; and (4) interpret and share the results with stakeholders.

The course gives students the opportunity to understand the importance of data and analytics to accounting and business management environments. Students complete case based problems throughout the course that require hands-on use of analytics tools. Students learn how data analytics can add value to business by providing powerful new insights to inform business decisions. Students learn to identify, interpret and use different forms of data to determine what is wrong and why it is so (technical accounting skills) as well how they would digitally communicate derived insights to stakeholders. 

Data and analytics are transforming business and have major implications for the role of graduate accountants in business. Increasingly, accountants are competing with data analysts and scientists. However, accountants are still the preferred trusted business advisors given their historic role in preparing financial information. This course is designed to give graduates a much sought after skill set which will equip them to add value to organizations in data driven business environments.

Acknowledgement is given to the Ernst & Young Foundation's Analytical Mindset Framework which informs the curriculum development of this course.

.
contentlets.title: Accounting Analytics for Business Decision Making

The Audit and Assurance (AAA) module examines and applies the relevant Auditing, Assurance and Ethics Standards to various scenarios. It is practical in nature with candidates required to apply the Standards to different scenarios, including a comprehensive case study which integrates Units 1 through 10 and a simulated case study which integrates Units 1, 11 and 12. The AAA module is one of the five (5) compulsory modules in the Chartered Accountants Program.

Management accounting continues to evolve. The traditional function of collating, preparing and presenting financial and non-financial information for decision making has changed. The way information is collated (including the increased use of data analytics) and the volume of data now available has had a significant impact. To add value, management accountants need to analyse and interpret the vast amount of available information in a concise manner, providing insight to enable management (and other users) to make informed decisions that align with strategic goals. Management accounting is forward looking and predictive analysis is becoming increasingly important in proactively guiding organisations in an ever changing business environment. Finance functions now partner closely with management accountants as the breadth of traditional management accounting concepts expand and integrate across all aspects of business. MAAF includes two integrated case studies and other practical examples and activities that will give you the skills and knowledge to identify, analyse, interpret and communicate information to help an organisation manage its resources and achieve strategic goals. Given the integration of the content covered in each unit of the MAAF module, the material has been constructed on the basis that candidates will complete each unit sequentially in order to maximise their learning benefit. The MAAF module is one of the five (5) compulsory modules in the Chartered Accountants Program.

The Taxation Australia (TAXAU) module examines and applies relevant Australian taxation law to various tax entities. It is practical in nature with candidates required to explain and calculate the taxation consequences applicable to a range of real-life simulated scenarios, including a comprehensive tax reconciliation which integrates the various units. The CA TAXAU module is one of the five (5) compulsory modules in the Chartered Accountants Program.

Open book exam consisting of four multi-part written questions based on course's learning outcomes. As an open book exam, students are able to bring any printed or handwritten resources they require. Three hour exam plus 15 minutes reading time. Students must PASS this exam to pass the module. A PASS mark is 40 marks out of 80 marks.

The Capstone module integrates knowledge and skills from the technical modules in developing the professional competence required to become a Chartered Accountant. While the module requires candidates to apply technical skills and current knowledge, the focus is on the development of competencies that candidates will need to perform effectively in the professional environment. Candidates attend three compulsory workshops throughout the module. Each workshop builds on activities and research completed to achieve the Capstone learning outcomes.

contentlets.description: The Capstone module integrates knowledge and skills from the technical modules in developing the professional competence required to become a Chartered Accountant. While the module requires candidates to apply technical skills and current knowledge, the focus is on the development of competencies that candidates will need to perform effectively in the professional environment. Candidates attend three compulsory workshops throughout the module. Each workshop builds on activities and research completed to achieve the Capstone learning outcomes.
contentlets.title: CA Module Capstone

Business School","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"ACCT5996 - Management Accounting and Business Analysis","description":"

This course examines the use of financial and non-financial information for the purpose of analysing business processes to achieve superior organisational performance. The course introduces a number of management accounting tools and quantitative techniques that can be used to analyse how business processes consume resources, create value for a firm and its customers, and how this value may be enhanced through business process improvement. The course draws on textbook explanations and research-based insights of contemporary business practice in this area.


Note: Not available to students who have completed ACCT2522 in the last three years.

contentlets.description:
This course examines the use of financial and non-financial information for the purpose of analysing business processes to achieve superior organisational performance. The course introduces a number of management accounting tools and quantitative techniques that can be used to analyse how business processes consume resources, create value for a firm and its customers, and how this value may be enhanced through business process improvement. The course draws on textbook explanations and research-based insights of contemporary business practice in this area.

Note: Not available to students who have completed ACCT2522 in the last three years.

accounting.","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"35c4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619ac","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

On the last day of the course you will be required to make a presentation to the class of a proposed research project. You should cover introduction, development of research questions or hypotheses and the research method. More details of this will be provided in class and on Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"35c4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619bd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3dc4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619bc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"3dc4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619bd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"75c4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619ae","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"75c4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619af","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"7dc4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619ad","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7dc4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619ae","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"7dc4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619af","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"06c4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619f5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1 - Literature Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

The first assignment will be a literature review leading to the development of research questions or hypotheses. The details of the literature review assignment will be provided during the course and on Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"35c4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619bd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3dc4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619bc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"3dc4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619bd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"75c4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619ae","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"75c4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619af","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"7dc4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619ad","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7dc4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619ae","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"7dc4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619af","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"75c4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619bf","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

Participation mark will be based on the quality of discussion in class, including any assigned presentations. Knowledge of the readings assigned and the interrelationships between these readings will be an important component of this mark. You will be required to complete an assignment for each class. This will involve the preparation of a one page typed (single spaced) response to a question set for each class. Your response should not exceed one page. The issues covered in the assignments will be discussed in class and you will be required to submit your assignment at the end of each class. Your contribution to class discussion will remain the primary determinant of the participation mark. While your one-page responses will represent a small component of this mark, their primary purpose is to assist you in preparing to make a meaningful contribution to class discussion. Participation will be discussed in more detail in the first class.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"35c4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619bd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3dc4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619bc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"3dc4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619bd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"75c4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619ae","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"75c4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619af","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"7dc4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619ad","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7dc4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619ae","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"7dc4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619af","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"79c4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619e2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"50","description":"

Students are required to sit for a final examination paper in this course. The exam will cover the entire course. It will be an open book exam. More details of the final examination will be provided towards the end of the course.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"35c4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619bd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3dc4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619bc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"3dc4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619bd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"75c4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619ae","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"75c4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619af","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"7dc4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619ad","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7dc4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619ae","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"7dc4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619af","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"92c4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619ff","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2 - Data Analysis","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

The data analysis assignment requires you to statistically analyse some data and write up your results as they would be presented in a research article. The details of the data analysis assignment will be provided during the course and on Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"35c4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619bd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3dc4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619bc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"3dc4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619bd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"75c4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619af","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"7dc4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619ad","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7dc4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619ae","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"7dc4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619af","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c6c4dec7dba13450be4672f5f39619ec","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/ACCT5997.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.description: Enrolment requires School Approval.This course considers the relationship between science and scientific method; provides an introduction to the interpretation of the key statistical techniques used in accounting research; and considers and reviews some of the principle research methods that have been used to address issues in accounting.
contentlets.title: Seminar in Research Methodology
